comments.commentBody:
Looks like a mug shot.

Well, it's not JS BACH, Paul ANKA, KOBE Bryant or U NU. Certainly not MIA HAM, Jimmy Durante or Parker's HAWK...

Jmes AGEE had better hair and more chin, I think

By elimination, I'm left with the young Gay TALESE.
I'll make that donut a Boston Creme.
Yes, but beware of generalizing.

Ha. Do BAs even require a calculus course. I'm deeply horrified that calculus isn't generally covered junior/senior year of high school for most students; don't get me started on the abysmally low requirements needed even for many supposedly STEM degrees.

The conventional assumption that a degree equates to intelligence and competency is a myth that needs to be laid to rest. We are furthering the decline of our nation and citizens with this new caste system. Not a measure of intellect, instead the willingness to tolerate debt to become a member of a club.

I would sooner hire an individual with an AS that achieved As and Bs in calculus and no debt, than BA with debt, that is condescending towards those beneath their educational level. The AS employee shows a responsible dedicated, conscientious worker. The BA employee as one who goes with the mainstream.

The students I have spoken to picked their major based on money, instead of what they love or have a predisposition for. Or what was cheapest and quickest.
We may need to adapt the Scandinavian culture here to get competent people in the right places - free education. Provide gifted individuals with accelerated classes and mentors. Pay not only tuition, but living costs.

But only if we want to remain a world class country.

I would give them a heads up about age discrimination. If they don't get some upper-level management skills or a position, they may find they are eventually considered too "old" to know as much as the new ambitious kids coming along behind them--and who are cheaper. The new kids will seem innovative and will seem to have a handle on whatever new technology there is at that time. And I hope that they've started saving for retirement for the same reason. Life is good now. I hope it lasts.

Good for them. There are plenty of non-orthodox career paths that turn out just fine. That said I do think there is value at working your way through one of those degrees via night school at some point as a back-up and personal goal but rushing to it first thing out of high school isn't necessary. I do very well for myself despite spending my first few years after highschool whittling away at this and that random job.

@Hmmmm. I'd be careful to assume. I didn't go to college straight out of high-school. I didn't even technically finish high-school depending on what your qualification of that degree is.

However I can tell you off the bat that statistically speaking I am technically more intelligent than over 99% of your 1% of the nation with PhDs and could state similar numbers for graduates of the "good schools".
I'm sure glad that neither of them wanted to be an astronomer or a physician.  Being a dishwasher is fine, but not if you dreamed of the stars or saving lives.

Boy, am I glad my adult sons didn't fall for this. Like their old Dad, they said "No thanks" to college after they figured out they were smarter than most of the teachers, which didn't take very long. One son apprenticed himself to a top-notch video artist and is now a news photographer/reporter at one of the top TV stations in the US. The other son waited a while to get into job market but he's enjoying himself learning the food service industry from the bottom up at a 5-star restaurant. Neither of my sons is in debt or living with their parents. And old Dad? He's a former journalist now working online at something he'd rather not disclose because it pays so well and it's so easy to do that any of these kids poor kids who are $100,000 in debt and grateful to be schlepping for lawyers would kill to have my job.

Many started jn the mailroom and files,got great experience and moved on to better jobsin the same company having the advantage of knowing who was who in the company and the accounts. Sadly this does not happen anymore. In great companies many CEO,s started in the Mailroom.
Perhaps they should try again.

Tell that to Jobs, Gates and Zuckerberg -- world-changers who all dropped out of college by their sophomore year. College is a training ground for "yes men," not geniuses. The main lesson in college is simple: Do what you're told.

Bill Gates got into Harvard. He was clearly going to be successful whether he graduated or not.

The vast majority of people without degrees are not Bill Gates.

In the bad old days, high school was divided into general, business and academic diplomas. The good thing was that the business kids were prepared for the kinds of jobs these college kids are now getting.
@Josh Hill - today, Spielberg would have been kicked out on the very first day by security.

Duffy, I agree with you that this is ridiculous. I've a master's degree, working on a second, and can't tell you the menial jobs I've worked through the years while I toiled away to 'prove myself.' It's horrible, and I do believe there is implicit classism and racism. We have to delete sexism from the equation, since women earn more and higher degrees than men. They do, however, still earn .72 for each dollar a man earns.

Case is point: I've never had a (male) boss with the educational credentialing i've earned. I have had two (male) supervisors with no degree. All of this is terribly unfair and honestly, I can't say I needed any of my degrees for the jobs I've had. Having said that, I'm no Bill Gates, etc etc etc., so to school and work I go and go and go.

As for you friend, I hate so much to say this, but during her 15 years as an insurance collector, it would have held her in good stead to at least have earned a 2-year degree. She could have achieved that by taking a class every other semester. Even knowing it's a game and unfair, would she be wiser to play the game and be in it, or to bemoan it as ludicrous and be in the untenable position she now occupies?

Here's the decision, from Liptak's article:

"The Florida Supreme Court suppressed the evidence, saying that prosecutors had not adequately established the reliability of Aldo’s nose through comprehensive documentation of his performance in earlier searches. Justice Kagan said the dog’s substantial training and certification sufficed."

SCOTUS unanimously reversed the Florida Supreme Court.
This would never be ratified.  Why would elected officials vote to cut off their mother's milk?

This people--or at least 5 of them--got their jobs because President who appointed them and the Senators who approved them were bought and sold.  It is no surprise that they are in favor of corruption.
Oh great, here we go.  Elections openly bought & paid for, courtesy of the Supreme Court.
Low unemployment, low inflation, moderate or higher GDP growth. Unhappy economies might have any combination of the opposite of these.

I refer you to the California Recall Circus of 2003, in which 135 "candidates" -- almost all of whom were neither viable candidates nor with the slightest intention to win -- exploited a similar offerings of what effectively became incredibly inexpensive television airtime for their "political campaigns". Many just used to raise their profile, some used it just for cheap laughs at the expense of the process itself, and for some it was both.

That's not going to scale nationwide.
Most of our Representatives and Senators are millionaires. They don't need their paychecks, any more than most of us need a penny laying on the ground.

Uh, the Congress controls spending. It's in the Constitution.

So this is on the Congress,

Um...good old-fashioned racism, that's why they don't address him as President Obama.
And some partisanship for an extra affront at one of our best presidents.
I always make a point to type President Obama as should everyone.
And it is always good to point that out every time you notice it.
The ugly American proliferates.
But they won't forever.

As I often like to suggest:
get rid of Fox and much of this temper tantrum childish stuff vanishes.
Fox is a huge national security threat.
So is Congress.

Enjoy your "retirement", Mr. Allen.
Johnny, we hardly knew ya.
I'm cool with that and with keeping it that way.
"horde"!

The purpose of a cruise ship is to disgorge a hoard of people into cheesy gift shops, and then efficiently transfer as many trashy chinese-made "authentic souvenirs" and T-shirts to said hoard as possible.
And terms limits for Supreme Court Justices.  20 years?  15?

Oops -- sorry, I had it backwards -- I just checked. The architects actually would have preferred to have had the Library along Sixth Ave., with the park in front of it, so that the building would have shown off to better advantage. It was the city that preferred to have it along Fifth, with room at the rear to expand, possibly.

The point about the rear facade remains the same, regardless of the precise position of the building.

SW, that's a more honest approach than just saying "Cut now!"

But...

How many dollars does cutting the DOD by 50% save"

How many dollars does withdrawing all troops in the middle east save?

How many dollars does ending foreign assistance in countries where democracy does not exist save?

If we're going to be talking about cutting spending to reduce the deficit, these are the types of hard questions we need answers to.

And the reality is, if and when we ask hard questions and get honest answers, we will see that deficit reduction is not as simple as saying "Cut now!"

Pete: Glad to see you are helping out Jaaaay............I'll give it a try.

"The American people are getting tired of something alright and they know exactly who's playing games with their lives and the Country's future.......

Hint: It ain't Bush anymore, either."
Question for those posting attacks on Allen: Did you have the same smug, Gingrichian self-righteous feelings about Bill Clinton back in 1998? Do you believe that he, too, have stepped down?
